As well as serving as a memoral for the common people, the buildings, festivals and ceremonies that commemorated historical events also had a political significance.Read the following texts A-C, which relate to buildings, festivals and ceremonies in various regions, and answer the questions (Questions 1-9) below.
(25 points)
A
(1)At the beginning of the 1890s, the World's Fair was held in Chicago, in the United States of America.Visitors were amazed by the group of buildings called the White City, which formed the heart of the venue.This was because the White City was built to resemble the architectural styles of antiquity, such as ancientRome, whereas at that time in Chicago, the new generation of architects had developed construction using steel, following progress in its practical application in the (2)latter half of the 19th century, resulting in the modern skyscrapers that they constructed becoming the focus of attention.The style of the White City enjoyed tremendous popularity.One of the reasons for this is thought to have been that the image of the (3)United States of America, which was in the process of expanding its influence overseas, was superimposed on the glory of the Roman Empire.Moreover, there was the aspect that the country had looked to Europe for its past as the source of its identity.

A
The history of education in ancientGreece is strongly linked to the history of the city.(1)In Athens, where democracy began to develop in around the 5th century BCE, people called Sophists had a major impact on the education of citizens involved in the politics of the city.They had a strong tendency to advocate the subjectivity of morals.On the other hand, there was also burgeoning activity on the part of philosophers who advocated that citizens live according to universal truths and morals.Subsequently, after (2)the cities of Greece lost their political autonomy due to the growing power of Macedonia, conspicuous activity emerged on the part of those who sought to advocate standards of conduct as citizens of the world, rather than citizens of a city-state, as well as preaching the peace of mind of individuals.Some of these ideas were absorbed by the society of Rome, which was developing from a city-state into a global empire, and was popularized as (3)Stoicism.

One can say that laws are a mirror reflecting the particular characteristics of the period or region in which they are made, and they are also deeply related to international politics.Read the following texts A-C, which relate to law and politics, and answer the questions (Questions 1-9) below.

(1)In the ancient civilizations in each part of the world, laws that took various forms emerged amid a diverse range of circumstances.For example, in China, from the (2)Spring and Autumn and Warring States periods to the Qin and Han periods, as well as li, which formed a code of social conduct, laws called lu [statutes] and ling [ordinances] were also enacted.The distinction between lu as the penal code and ling as administrative laws was established in the statutes and ordinances promulgated during the Taishi reign period of the Jin (Western Jin) period, but supplementary legal provisions were subsequently put in place in the form of ge [rulings] and shi [models], so by the time of the Sui period, a legal system consisting of lu, ling, ge and shi had been established.The system of lu and ling in the (3)Sui period and the Tang period that followed it was introduced to various regions in East Asia, including Korea and Japan, and came to play a major role in the formation of nations in those regions.
